messages.author: Maria Chen (CyberSynth)
messages.content:
## [**Maria Chen**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fakeprofile1) 

*Founder & Lead AI Architect @ [CyberSynth](https://cybersynth.dev) · We build secure, decentralized AI systems.*

Hi everyone! I've been in the cybersecurity space for over a decade, transitioning into AI security about 3 years ago. I'm a big believer in open-source and building tools that empower developers. In my other life, I'm a competitive rock climber.

Special power: Can debug race conditions in my sleep.

📍 San Francisco, CA (PST)

messages.author: David Lee (DataWeave)
messages.content:
## [**David Lee**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fakeprofile2)
*Head of Data @ [DataWeave](https://dataweave.io) · Making data pipelines intelligent and autonomous.*

Hello! I'm David. I've been wrestling with large-scale data systems for my entire career, from Hadoop clusters to modern data lakes. Now I'm focused on applying LLMs to data engineering workflows. I also contribute to Apache Arrow.

Special power: I roast my own coffee beans. The perfect pour-over is my art form.

📍 London, UK (GMT)

messages.author: Sofia Rodriguez (LogicLoom)
messages.content:
## [Sofia Rodriguez](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fakeprofile3)

*Co-founder & CEO @ [LogicLoom](https://logicoom.ai) · LogicLoom is a platform for building and verifying complex agentic workflows. Think of it as unit testing for AI agents.*

Hey all! I'm a former philosophy professor turned tech entrepreneur. My passion is at the intersection of formal logic and machine learning. LogicLoom is my attempt to bring more rigor and reliability to the AI space.

Special power: I can recite the first 200 digits of pi. It's a completely useless but fun party trick.

📍 Berlin, DE (CET)

messages.author: Alex Ivanov (CogniCore)
messages.content:
## [**Alex Ivanov**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fakeprofile4/)
*Senior ML Engineer @ [CogniCore](https://cognicore.tech) · We're creating next-gen multimodal models for creative industries.*

Hey everyone, I'm Alex. I have a background in computer graphics and generative art. At CogniCore, I work on models that can understand and generate video, audio, and text seamlessly. I'm always down to talk about diffusion models or creative AI.

Special power: I built a robot that paints abstract art.

📍 Tokyo, JP (JST)

messages.author: Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)
messages.content:
## [**Chloe Dubois**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/fakeprofile5/)
*CTO @ [Aether AI](https://aetherai.com) · Building efficient AI for edge devices.*

Hi! I'm Chloe. My focus is on model optimization, quantization, and running complex neural networks on resource-constrained hardware. Before Aether, I was at a major chip designer working on their mobile AI accelerators. When I'm not coding, I'm usually hiking in the mountains.

📍 Grenoble, FR (CET)

messages.author: Alex Ivanov (CogniCore)
messages.content:
Almost zero, the official implementation wasn't optimized for consumer hardware. The comparable open model is probably Llama-3.1 405B, which is impossible for me to run. The benefit here is getting near-SoTA reasoning in total privacy with very fast token generation. It's not beating the top-tier proprietary models, but for local use, it's a game changer.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: This is a great write-up on potential security issues with MCP and database tools.

embeds.title: How an Agent Can Exfiltrate Your Database via an Insecure MCP
embeds.description: We demonstrate an attack vector where a malicious actor can leverage an LLM agent's tool-use capabilities to access and leak sensitive data from a connected database through the Model Context Protocol.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Big news: MCP now supports authentication via common providers. This is a huge step forward for security.

embeds.title: Securing Your Agents: MCP Now Supports Authentication
embeds.description: You can now protect your MCP servers and require user authentication before an AI agent can access its tools. Here's a quick demo showing how to implement it...

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: The leading open-source agent, Nexus, just added support for remote MCP servers a few weeks ago.

embeds.title: Nexus Agent Now Supports Remote MCP
embeds.description: Today we're announcing support for remote MCP servers in Nexus Agent. This allows you to connect to tools and services without running a local server.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: The lead of the Open Source Initiative on MCP:

embeds.title: MCP: The TCP/IP Moment for Artificial Intelligence
embeds.description: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is emerging as a critical communication standard for AI systems, much like HTTP was for the web. Here's why it matters for the future of open source AI.

They're afraid of picking the 'wrong' horse. So it's less about a specific agent and more about the instability of the whole ecosystem.

embeds.title: The Generative AI Infrastructure Gap: 8 Protocols We Need Now
embeds.description: The rapid evolution of AI is creating architectural debt. These are the 8 critical patterns and protocols we need to define to build the next generation of AI infrastructure.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Cloudflare is more 'near-edge' than true edge. Their massive network of PoPs creates an edge-like experience with low latency, but you're still running in their data centers.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: The key difference is that 'local' compute is highly heterogeneous (different OS, CPU, RAM), while 'edge' compute (like Cloudflare Workers) is a standardized, homogeneous environment.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: I distinguish between 'local' and 'edge' based on the compute environment's nature.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: If it's running in the browser via WebAssembly, I'd call that edge.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Right, if it's running on your machine via a CLI tool, that's 'local'.

messages.author: Lucas Müller (ConnectSphere)
messages.content: Got it. So it doesn't have to be on a remote server. An MCP running on the user's device to control local applications would also be considered 'at the edge'.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content:
Exactly. When I say Edge+MCP, I'm talking about running the MCP server itself in an edge environment, close to the user.

In reply to Lucas Müller (ConnectSphere)'s message:
What's the distinction you're making with 'Edge+MCP'? MCP is just a protocol; it can run anywhere. I'm currently building a demo where the LLM runs locally in-browser with transformers.js, and it communicates with both remote MCPs and a local MCP that controls the web app's UI.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Mozilla's recent work on Wasm agents is super relevant here.

embeds.title: Wasm Agents: Trustworthy AI in Your Browser
embeds.description: We explore how to build AI agents that run entirely client-side using WebAssembly, ensuring privacy and eliminating server costs.

messages.author: Lucas Müller (ConnectSphere)
messages.content: What's the distinction you're making with 'Edge+MCP'? MCP is just a protocol; it can run anywhere. I'm currently building a demo where the LLM runs locally in-browser with transformers.js, and it communicates with both remote MCPs and a local MCP that controls the web app's UI.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Great, I'll send you a connection request and a calendar invite.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Yes, let's connect. I think there's a huge opportunity here.

messages.author: Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)
messages.content: Let's set up a call with our engineering team. We've been focused on the Wasm runtime, but we're actively exploring killer applications for it in the AI space.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: To be clear, I'm thinking about MCPs that act as gateways to external APIs, not MCPs that perform local actions on the device.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content:
This is exactly what I was hoping to hear! 😍

In reply to Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)'s message:
Interesting. We can definitely do something with our new edge component runtime, which is based on Wasm.

messages.author: Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)
messages.content: Interesting. We can definitely do something with our new edge component runtime, which is based on Wasm.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Think about it: right now, agent developers have to host their own MCP servers because there are few reliable, managed options. SaaS companies will be forced to offer their own managed MCP endpoints for their APIs. If they can offer these as secure, sandboxed Wasm components that run on the edge, they offload compute costs and reduce latency. It's a huge win.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: Instead of spinning up a server just to run a headless browser for a web scraping tool.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: The idea of combining Edge compute with MCP for browser automation agents is a game-changer.

messages.author: Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics)
messages.content: So, is there a simple way to convert an MCP that communicates over stdio (like from a CLI tool) into something that can run on the edge? Cloudflare Workers now supports MCPs, which is close. But that requires rewriting the tool logic in a worker-compatible format. I'm looking for a lazy path for my friend Bob.

messages.author: Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)
messages.content: Hey Noah Kim (Apex Dynamics), you've come to the right place. 😉 Edge + MCP is going to be a massive trend.

messages.content: Chloe Dubois (Aether AI)

messages.author: Arnaud Porterie (Vibe)
messages.content: Here's a comment from one of the study's authors clarifying their methodology. They acknowledge the limitations.

messages.author: Arnaud Porterie (Vibe)
messages.content: Even if it only proves that there's a steep learning curve for effectively using AI tools, that's a valuable finding in itself.

messages.author: William Johnson (ByteForge)
messages.content:
Exactly. And their sample size is tiny. It takes weeks of deliberate practice to get good at prompting and working with an AI pair programmer. You can't just drop it on someone and expect immediate productivity gains.

In reply to Ethan Brown (CodeFlow)'s message:
That's a fair point about the study's methodology. In the real world, developers use their judgment to decide when an AI tool is appropriate for a task. You wouldn't use it for complex architectural decisions, but you might for writing boilerplate or tests. Randomly assigning tasks ignores this crucial element of developer choice and expertise.

messages.author: Ethan Brown (CodeFlow)
messages.content:
That's a fair point about the study's methodology. In the real world, developers use their judgment to decide when an AI tool is appropriate for a task. You wouldn't use it for complex architectural decisions, but you might for writing boilerplate or tests. Randomly assigning tasks ignores this crucial element of developer choice and expertise.

I understand why the researchers did it—to avoid selection bias—but a more realistic experiment might involve letting developers choose which tasks they think are AI-suitable, and then randomizing within that pool.

messages.author: Arnaud Porterie (Vibe)
messages.content: I'm sure everyone has seen this study from Acme Research on AI's impact on developer productivity.

embeds.title: Measuring the Real-World Impact of AI on Experienced Developers
embeds.description: Our latest study finds that while AI coding assistants can improve speed on simple tasks, they show no significant productivity gain on complex, open-ended software engineering problems.

messages.author: Ethan Brown (CodeFlow)
messages.content:
Great interview. His perspective on AGI and simulation is fascinating. Thanks for sharing.

In reply to Kenji Tanaka (NeuroNet)'s message:
New interview with John Romero just dropped.

messages.author: Kenji Tanaka (NeuroNet)
messages.content: New interview with John Romero just dropped.

embeds.title: John Romero on the Future of AGI, Game Development, and Simulated Worlds
embeds.description: The legendary creator of Doom shares his thoughts on where AI is heading and its potential to revolutionize gaming and create truly intelligent NPCs.

messages.author: Ben Carter (Momentum ML)
messages.content:
If you like strategy games, check out '0 A.D.', it's a full-fledged, open-source RTS like Age of Empires. For shooters, 'Xonotic' is a classic arena FPS with a great community.

In reply to Julien Seveno (Lightpanda 🐼)'s message:
I'm looking for something that's complex enough to be interesting, but with a codebase that's approachable for a side project.

embeds.title: Xonotic - The Free and Fast Arena Shooter
embeds.description: A free and fast-paced first-person shooter for Windows, macOS, and Linux.

messages.author: Mia Johansson (GameCraft AI)
messages.content: I'm looking for something that's complex enough to be interesting, but with a codebase that's approachable for a side project.

messages.author: Mia Johansson (GameCraft AI)
messages.content:
I was thinking of trying to implement some RL algorithms for NPC behavior, and maybe add some LLM-powered dialogue.

In reply to Ben Carter (Momentum ML)'s message:
Sure, there are tons. What kind of game are you interested in?

messages.author: Kenji Tanaka (NeuroNet)
messages.content: Any game made with the Godot engine is open source by nature!

messages.author: Ben Carter (Momentum ML)
messages.content:
Sure, there are tons. What kind of game are you interested in?

In reply to Mia Johansson (GameCraft AI)'s message:
Does anyone know of any good open-source games that are fun to hack on?

messages.author: Mia Johansson (GameCraft AI)
messages.content: Does anyone know of any good open-source games that are fun to hack on?

messages.author: Ben Carter (Momentum ML)
messages.content: The new console from 'Playdate' looks so cool.

embeds.title: Playdate - A New Handheld Gaming System
embeds.description: It's yellow. It fits in your pocket. It has a beautiful black and white screen. And it has a crank.

messages.author: Maria Chen (CyberSynth)
messages.content: We're hosting a casual rooftop get-together tomorrow in SF for folks in the AI space. If you're around and want to talk shop over some drinks and snacks, come by! Lucas Müller (ConnectSphere) will be there too!

embeds.title: The AI Founders Mixer · Luma
embeds.description: A casual networking event for AI founders, researchers, and builders. Join us on the rooftop for good conversation and great views.

messages.author: Leo Schmidt (Bio-Nexus)
messages.content:
Perfect, thank you so much!
